content: How can I help you today?

I’ve just been really stressed out lately, and it’s making it hard to sleep. I feel like my mind won’t shut off at night, and I can’t stop worrying about work and how I’m going to take care of my family. It’s all just a lot right now.

It sounds like you're under a lot of pressure lately, and it's affecting your sleep. Stress about work and taking care of your family seems to be weighing heavily on your mind. Dealing with so much responsibility can be overwhelming, and it's understandable that this is hard for you. How have you been managing all of this so far?

Honestly, I don’t think I’ve been managing very well. At night, when my thoughts won’t stop racing, I usually end up scrolling on my phone just to distract myself. But I know it doesn’t really help—it just seems to give me more to think about.

It sounds like scrolling on your phone has been a way to try and escape the overwhelming thoughts, even though it hasn’t brought the relief you were hoping for. It’s understandable that you’re looking for any way to ease the stress and get through the moment. What do you think you need most right now to feel some relief or support?
I’m not really sure, to be honest. I feel stuck, like nothing I do is really helping. I just want to be able to sleep and not feel exhausted all the time, but I don’t even know where to start.

Feeling stuck can be really frustrating, especially when it feels like you're trying but nothing is helping. Wanting to improve your sleep and feel less exhausted is such an important goal, especially since it could help with the stress you're dealing with too. It sounds like you're searching for a way to get out of this cycle—what do you think has stopped you from making any changes so far?

I think it’s just overwhelming. Like, I don’t even know what changes to make or where to start, and when I’m so exhausted, the idea of trying anything new feels impossible. Plus, there’s this little part of me that wonders if it’ll even work, you know? So I end up doing nothing.

Feeling overwhelmed and unsure of where to start makes total sense, especially when you're already exhausted and questioning whether any changes will make a difference. It’s a lot to think about, and it can feel discouraging when your energy is so low. Yet it seems like you still care about finding a solution, even if it feels out of reach right now. What really matters to you when it comes to getting through this period of stress and exhaustion?

I guess what really matters to me is being there for my family. I want to be a good provider, a good partner, and a good dad, but right now, I feel like I’m failing at all of it. I just want to feel like myself again so I can show up for them the way I want to.

Wanting to be there for your family, to be a good partner and dad, shows how deeply you care about them and how much they mean to you. It sounds like feeling overwhelmed has made you feel disconnected from the version of yourself you want to be, which is really tough. You’re carrying so much responsibility while also not feeling like yourself—it’s a difficult place to be. What do you think could help you start moving toward feeling more like yourself again?

Maybe if I could just sleep better, I’d have the energy to deal with everything else. But I don’t even know how to make that happen with all these thoughts in my head every night. And honestly, I feel like sleep is just one piece of a bigger problem. What if I fix that, but I’m still just stressed out all the time?

It sounds like sleep feels like an important first step for you, but you’re also recognizing that it’s part of a larger picture—the stress and everything that’s been weighing you down. It’s understandable to worry about whether improving one piece, like sleep, will be enough when there’s still so much going on. It seems like you want to address not just the exhaustion but also the deeper stress that’s been holding you back. What do you think would be different if you were able to manage the stress alongside improving your sleep?

Maybe I’d feel more in control, not so stuck. If I could manage the stress better, I think I’d be less overwhelmed, and maybe then I could focus more on my family and work without feeling like I’m constantly falling apart. But I don’t even know how to deal with the stress—I’ve never been good at that.

You’ve shared something really meaningful—the idea of feeling more in control and less overwhelmed, which could give you the space to focus on what matters most in your life. Stress has been tough for you to manage, and it’s easy to feel stuck when you’re not sure where to turn or how to start. Even so, you’re exploring what would make a difference for you, and that’s an important step. What do you think is keeping you from finding a way to manage the stress right now?

I think part of it is just not knowing what works for me. I’ve never really learned how to manage stress in a healthy way, and when things feel so overwhelming, I don’t even know where to begin. It’s like I don’t trust myself to know how to fix things, so I just avoid dealing with it altogether.

It sounds like not knowing what works for you has made it harder to even start addressing the stress. When things feel overwhelming, it makes sense that avoidance feels easier—it’s a way of protecting yourself from more frustration or even failure. But the fact that you’re here, talking about all this, shows that deep down you have the strength and desire to make things better. What do you think would help you feel more confident in figuring out, little by little, how to manage stress in a way that works for you?

Perhaps having someone guide me or break things down into small, manageable steps might help. If I didn’t feel like I had to figure everything out all at once, maybe I could start somewhere and build from there. It feels like I could use some support or tools to actually make those changes stick.

Having support and breaking things down into smaller, manageable steps sounds like a really thoughtful way to approach this—it’s about moving forward without feeling overwhelmed by trying to tackle everything all at once. You’re showing a lot of insight by identifying what could make it easier for you to start finding what works and making lasting changes. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before we discuss how you might take those small steps toward managing stress and improving sleep?
No, I think that’s everything for now. I’m open to hearing more about small steps I can take.
